Hmm okay, that makes sense!

Regarding the large gradients: I numerically computed the gradient by perturbing input[0, 2] by a small amount and looking at how much it changes the output and it looks like something around 1e+24 is reasonable for the gradient. The output seems to be high because of the .exp() operation (one of the inputs to that was 41 from a quick glance). I'll look more into this tomorrow
